Hi! I've been working on a Lean project and developed some infrastructure that might be useful for Mathlib:

ℓ^1_ν as a commutative unital Banach algebra:

Mathlib has:

  • Standard ℓ^p: lp E p with ‖f‖ = (∑ ‖fₙ‖^p)^{1/p}
  • NormedRing / NormedAlgebra only for p = ∞
  • PowerSeries R (algebraic, no norms)

I have:

  • Weighted ℓ^p_ν: ‖f‖ = (∑ |νⁿfₙ|^p)^{1/p}
  • For p = 1: Full NormedRing and NormedAlgebra ℝ instances (w.r.t. Cauchy product)
  • Submultiplicativity: ‖a ⋆ b‖_{ℓ^1_ν} ≤ ‖a‖ · ‖b‖, where ⋆ is the Cauchy product
  • CompleteSpace
  • This result could potentially apply to the general ℓ^1 space, as the proofs rely on Summable. My work specializes in weighted ℓ^1 (ℓ^1_ν)

RM:
ℓ^1 with pointwise multiplication is a non-unital Banach algebra.
ℓ^1 with Cauchy product is a commutative UNITAL Banach algebra (with unit δ₀ = (1, 0, 0, ...)).

The weight ν controls the radius of convergence when interpreting
elements as power series. This bridges algebraic power series
to analytic function spaces. The submultiplicativity proof uses antidiagonal sums.

The Cauchy product on sequences is given by (a ⋆ b)ₙ = Σ_{k∈antidiagonal(n)} aₖ bₙ₋ₖ, which is exactly PowerSeries multiplication (toPowerSeries_mul). I use this to transport ring axioms from Mathlib's CommSemiring (PowerSeries R), then add the ℓ^1 norm structure with submultiplicativity.

Are any of these already in Mathlib or too trivial to be made into a new lemma? Would PRs be welcome?

Please let me know if my description of what Mathlib has is inaccurate.

Code: https://github.com/IlPreteRosso/LEANearized-RadiiPolynomial

@Ian Jauslin Hello Ian! Sorry that I never got back to you after the brief talk about having trouble with leanblueprint during the Lean seminar. That problem has been solved in a recent PR. However, I made some changes to blueprint.yml, fixed out of disk space error, and added cache to optimize for speed across runs. Also changed to texlive-smal for a faster image pull. Details can be seen in my repo above. I'd love to know whether this is worth pushing to the main repo.

Making them a PR would certainly be welcome! I don't think we have much of this, and at any rate the best way to exactly compare what you have done with what is currently in the library is through PR's. I don't know if you have already opened PR's to Mathlib, and if not it is probably wise to first have a look at this page: there are many very useful suggestions, often crucial for reviewers to actively work on your PR, but perhaps the most important one is the sentence

If you've made a lot of changes/additions, try to make many PRs containing small, self-contained pieces; in general, the smaller the better!

You can then mention here the PR number(s) for people to start looking at them.
